item.title: In a first, 1,990 adults take BCG vaccine in Mumbai - The Times of India
item.description:
First BCG Vaccine Administration to 1,990 Adults in Mumbai

Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

This landmark event marks the first time nearly 2,000 adults in Mumbai received the BCG vaccine. The initiative aims to enhance public health and combat tuberculosis in the region.

  • 1,990 adults received the BCG vaccine.
  • The vaccination drive is part of a larger public health initiative.
  • BCG vaccine is primarily used to protect against tuberculosis.
“This vaccination initiative signifies a major step forward in our fight against tuberculosis,” said health officials.

The successful administration of the BCG vaccine to a large number of adults could significantly impact tuberculosis prevention efforts in Mumbai and beyond.

item.title: Why So SAD? Blame It On Winter - The Times of India
item.description:
Why So SAD? Blame It On Winter

Published on: Unknown | Source: Unknown

As winter sets in, many individuals may experience Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD), which can lead to feelings of sadness and depression. This article explores the reasons behind these winter blues and potential coping strategies.

  • Winter months can contribute to lowered mood and energy levels.
  • Factors include reduced sunlight exposure and significant lifestyle changes.
  • Common symptoms of SAD include fatigue, depression, and changes in sleep patterns.
  • Strategies to combat SAD include light therapy, exercise, and seeking professional help.
“Understanding the impact of seasons on our mental health is crucial for managing well-being during winter.”

Addressing SAD is vital for improving mental health and overall quality of life during the challenging winter months.

item.title: Vitamin D has no role to play in preventing fractures: New Research - The Times of India
item.description:
Vitamin D has no role to play in preventing fractures: New Research

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: Unspecified

This article discusses new research which concludes that vitamin D does not prevent fractures, challenging previously held beliefs about its benefits for bone health.

  • New research indicates that vitamin D supplementation does not reduce the risk of fractures.
  • The study contradicts earlier studies that suggested a protective role of vitamin D for bones.
  • The findings could change recommendations for vitamin D intake in older adults.
"The data shows no significant evidence supporting vitamin D's role in fracture prevention."

This research might shift how healthcare providers approach bone health management, particularly for the elderly population.

item.title: Harvard University shares 7 tips to keep your memory sharp at any age - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Harvard University shares 7 tips to keep your memory sharp at any age

Publication Date: December 20, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

As we age, remembering things can become more difficult. Harvard University offers seven effective tips to help enhance memory at any age.

  • Keep Learning: Engaging in advanced education stimulates mental activity.
  • Use All Your Senses: Involving multiple senses can boost memory retention.
  • Believe in Yourself: Positive belief in your memory abilities can improve retention.
  • Economize Your Brain Use: Utilize tools like calendars and lists for essential information.
  • Repeat What You Want to Know: Reinforcing information helps strengthen memory.
  • Space It Out: Timing your repetitions can greatly enhance memory retention.
  • Make a Mnemonic: Create catchy phrases to memorize information effectively.
“Positive thoughts about memory preservation work for all age groups.”

By incorporating these tips, individuals can work towards maintaining their memory and cognitive health as they age.

item.title: Yemen bears world’s highest cholera burden, deepening humanitarian crisis - UN News
item.description:
Yemen bears world’s highest cholera burden, deepening humanitarian crisis

Publication Date: 23 December 2024 Source: UN News

Yemen has reported the highest global burden of cholera, with nearly 250,000 suspected cases and 861 associated deaths as of 1 December 2024, accounting for 35% of worldwide cholera cases this year.

  • Caseloads rose by 37% and deaths by 27% in November compared to 2023.
  • The ongoing cholera crisis is exacerbated by nine years of conflict and severe funding shortages.
  • Yemen's cholera response faces a $20 million funding gap from October 2024 to March 2025.
  • Currently, 84% of treatment centers are at risk of closure due to lack of funds.
  • The WHO has mobilized extensive resources to combat the outbreak, including vaccinations for 3.2 million people.
“The outbreak of waterborne diseases like cholera... imposes an additional burden on an already stressed health system.” - Arturo Pesigan, WHO Representative in Yemen

Failure to secure immediate financial support could lead to catastrophic outcomes similar to the 2017-2020 outbreak, putting millions at risk.

item.title: 'I Couldn't Write My Name': This 24-Year-Old Survived Deadly Brain Disorder, Know Signs Of Moyamoya Disease - Times Now
item.description:
‘I Couldn't Write My Name’: This 24-Year-Old Survived Deadly Brain Disorder, Know Signs Of Moyamoya Disease

Publication Date: February 2024 Source: Times Now

Chee Ming Heng, a 24-year-old student, faced a life-threatening condition called moyamoya disease, which began with seemingly harmless symptoms like difficulty in writing. His experience reveals the severity of this rare brain disorder.

  • Chee began to struggle with writing and holding objects in February 2024.
  • Moyamoya disease is characterized by blocked arteries at the base of the brain, leading to stroke risks.
  • Chee underwent bypass surgery on May 10 to restore blood flow.
  • After a slow recovery, he has regained normal functions and maintains a positive outlook.
“Now that I know how serious it was, I can say, ‘Well, I survived a stroke!’” - Chee Ming Heng

The journey from initial misdiagnosis to successful surgery highlights the importance of awareness regarding moyamoya disease and its symptoms.

item.title: 10 health benefits of eating black pepper regularly - The Times of India
item.description:
10 Health Benefits of Eating Black Pepper Regularly

Published on: Published time: October 27, 2023 | Source: TOI Lifestyle Desk

Black pepper is often referred to as the 'king of spices' and offers multiple health benefits, including boosting metabolism and enhancing digestion. Here are 10 reasons to include black pepper in your diet.

  • Boosts metabolism and promotes fat burning.
  • Rich in antioxidants, fighting oxidative stress.
  • Helps relieve cough and cold symptoms.
  • Aids digestion and enhances nutrient absorption.
  • Stimulates blood circulation for better cardiovascular health.
  • Promotes skin health with antibacterial properties.
  • Enhances brain function and memory.
  • Supports immune function with antimicrobial properties.
  • Improves absorption of essential nutrients like curcumin.
  • Contains anti-inflammatory compounds.

item.title: Clearing the Air: The Influence of Vaping on Smoking Cessation - Pharmacy Times
item.description:
Clearing the Air: The Influence of Vaping on Smoking Cessation

Publication Date: September 14, 2024 | Source: Pharmacy Times

This article discusses the role of pharmacists in addressing nicotine addiction through FDA-approved smoking cessation methods and highlights the risks of vaping compared to traditional smoking.

  • Pharmacists are essential in educating patients on nicotine addiction and safe smoking cessation.
  • E-cigarettes have significant health risks and have not proven effective for quitting smoking.
  • Evidence suggests that e-cigarettes may lead to dual use with traditional cigarettes, increasing health risks.
  • Vaping has surged among youth, contributing to a nicotine addiction epidemic.
  • The FDA recommends several safe and effective smoking cessation aids.
“Pharmacists should guide patients toward FDA-approved agents and not recommend the use of e-cigarettes due to lack of supportive data.”

In conclusion, pharmacists play a critical role in providing education and support for smoking cessation, emphasizing the importance of FDA-approved therapies over vaping.

item.title: BMC launches adult BCG vaccination campaign to combat TB - The Indian Express
item.description:
BMC launches adult BCG vaccination campaign to combat TB

Publication Date: December 23, 2023

Source: Indian Express

The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) has introduced an adult Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccination drive aimed at addressing the tuberculosis (TB) crisis in Mumbai, which commenced on December 23 with 1,990 vaccinations administered across 12 wards.

  • The BCG vaccine has typically been given to newborns, but is now being offered to adults.
  • BMC Commissioner Bhushan Gagrani encourages eligible citizens to participate.
  • In 2023, Mumbai reported over 50,000 active TB cases.
  • The initiative is part of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme targeting TB eradication by 2025.
  • Vulnerable groups include those treated for TB in the past five years, household contacts, diabetics, smokers, malnourished individuals, and seniors aged 60 and above.
  • The Cy-TB test, introduced for early detection of latent TB, is cost-effective according to ICMR–NIRT studies.
“This initiative is a vital step in our fight against TB. I encourage every eligible citizen to contact their nearest health centre or TB programme staff and take advantage of this opportunity.” - Bhushan Gagrani, BMC Commissioner

In conclusion, the BMC's adult BCG vaccination campaign represents a proactive approach to combating tuberculosis in high-risk populations, supplementing ongoing health initiatives within the city.

item.title: Keto vs Paleo diet: Experts suggest which one to pick for guaranteed weight loss - The Times of India
item.description:
Keto vs Paleo diet: Experts suggest which one to pick for guaranteed weight loss

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

As the New Year approaches, many are reconsidering their dietary choices, particularly the popular keto and paleo diets known for their weight loss benefits due to restrictive food intake.

  • The keto diet is a high-fat, low-carb diet that shifts the body's energy source from glucose to fat.
  • The paleo diet mimics the eating habits of early humans, focusing on whole, unprocessed foods while eliminating grains, dairy, and processed foods.
  • Both diets have shown short-term weight loss, but long-term sustainability and environmental impact are concerns.
“They’re terrible for the environment and fairly unsustainable.” - Federica Amati

Choosing between keto and paleo depends on individual health goals and dietary preferences, making it important to consult healthcare providers before committing to a strict diet.

item.title: WHO looks back at 2024 - World Health Organization
item.description:
WHO Looks Back at 2024

Published on: 23 December 2024 | Source: World Health Organization

2024 was a complex year for global health, with many highlights and breakthroughs. WHO reflects on significant accomplishments, challenges faced, and hopes for a healthier 2025.

  • Elimination of multiple neglected tropical diseases in seven countries including Brazil and Chad.
  • Egypt and Cabo Verde achieved malaria-free certification.
  • Record reductions in deaths from drowning worldwide.
  • Global tobacco use decreased, although youth usage remains a concern.
  • The launch of the first Global Report on the Commercial Determinants of Health scheduled for 2025.
  • Continued negotiations on a global pandemic agreement to improve international collaboration.
“We find ourselves in a time where fake news, lies, conspiracy theories, misinformation, and disinformation are rampant.” - Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

As WHO concludes another year of efforts, it thanks all partners and health workers for their unwavering support in achieving these victories and looks ahead to further advancements in public health.

item.title: Coffee, tea may protect against head & neck cancer: Study - Greater Kashmir
item.description:
Coffee and Tea May Lower Risk of Head and Neck Cancer, Study Finds

Date: Dec 23, 2021
Source: Greater Kashmir

Consumption of coffee and tea can lower the risks of developing head and neck cancer, including cancers of the mouth and throat, according to a study published in the CANCER journal.

  • Drinking more than 4 cups of caffeinated coffee daily linked with 17% lower odds of head and neck cancer overall.
  • 3-4 cups of caffeinated coffee linked with 41% lower risk of having hypopharyngeal cancer.
  • Drinking decaffeinated coffee associated with 25% lower odds of oral cavity cancer.
  • Drinking tea linked with 29% lower odds of hypopharyngeal cancer.

“While there has been prior research on coffee and tea consumption and reduced risk of cancer, this study highlighted their varying effects with different sub-sites of head and neck cancer, including the observation that even decaffeinated coffee had some positive impact.”
— Yuan-Chin Amy Lee, senior author

Head and neck cancer is the seventh most common cancer worldwide, and rates are rising in low- and middle-income countries.

item.title: Is Male Menopause Real? Everything To Know About Andropause And Hormonal Fluctuations In Older Men - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Is Male Menopause Real? Everything To Know About Andropause And Hormonal Fluctuations In Older Men

Publication Date: 2024-12-01 Source: The Health Site

This article explores the reality of male menopause, also known as andropause, discussing its symptoms, causes, and recommended lifestyle changes.

  • Andropause is characterized by hormonal fluctuations as men age, particularly a decline in testosterone levels.
  • Symptoms may include fatigue, mood swings, decreased libido, and loss of muscle mass.
  • Timely management of symptoms is essential for improving overall well-being.
  • Men are encouraged to maintain physical activity, a balanced diet, and avoid unhealthy substances during this period.
  • Consultation with healthcare professionals is important for personalized management of andropause.
“It is imperative to understand the situation better from a doctor, who can guide you with lifestyle changes and help you to manage the symptoms.” - Dr. Mansi Sharma

The understanding and approach to male menopause need to be elevated similarly to women's health discussions, highlighting the importance of addressing these health issues openly.

item.title: 10 Beautiful Flowers That Kill Mosquitoes - Times Now
item.description:
10 Beautiful Flowers That Kill Mosquitoes

Publication Date: Dec 23, 2024 Source: Times Now

This article explores a selection of attractive flowers that are effective in repelling mosquitoes, combining aesthetics with functionality in gardening.

  • Marigolds contain pyrethrum, a natural mosquito repellent.
  • Lavender's fragrance deters mosquitoes while adding beauty to gardens.
  • Citronella grass, known for its use in repellents, produces yellow flowers that repel mosquitoes.
  • Lemon balm has a strong scent that keeps mosquitoes at bay.
  • Basil has a strong aroma and is effective in mosquito deterrence.
  • Peppermint flowers are known for their strong minty scent that repels mosquitoes.
  • Bee balm attracts pollinators and repels mosquitoes with its fragrant oils.
  • Catnip contains nepetalactone, a compound that repels mosquitoes.
  • Tansy has strong aroma that helps discourage mosquitoes.
  • Geraniums, especially citronella varieties, have natural mosquito-repelling properties.
